The Key Laboratory of Fuel Cell for Guangdong Province School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, South China University of Technology Guangzhou Guangdong 510640 China Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), such as polyethylene oxide (PEO), are characteristic of good flexibility and excellent processability, but they suffer from low ionic conductivity and small Li+ transference number at ambient temperature. Inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs), garnet-type Li7La3Zr2O12 and its derivatives (LLZO-based) in particular, possess high ionic conductivity at room temperature, wide electrochemical stability window, large Li+ transference number as well as good stability against Li metal anode. Nevertheless, lithium dendrites growth, interfacial contact issue and brittle nature of LLZO-based ceramic electrolytes prevent their practical applications. In response to these shortcomings, LLZO-based/polymer solid composite electrolytes (SCEs), taking complementary advantages of two kinds of electrolytes, and thus simultaneously improving the electrode wettability, ionic conductivity and mechanical strength, have been made to develop high-performance SCEs in recent years. Herein, the intrinsic properties and research progress of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs, including LLZO-based/PEO SCEs (LLZO-based/PEO SCEs with uniform dispersion of LLZO-based fillers and LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs) and LLZO-based/novel polymers SCEs, are summarized. Besides, comprehensive updates on their applications in solid-state batteries are also presented. Finally, challenges and perspectives of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs for advanced all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs) are suggested. This review paper aims to provide systematic research progress of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs, to allow for more efficient and target-oriented research on improving LLZO-based/polymer SCEs. Graphical abstract This study reviewed the research progress of intrinsic properties of the LLZO-based/polymer solid composite electrolytes and their potential application in solid-state lithium batteries, aiming to provide more efficient and target-oriented research on improving them. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Solid polymer electrolyte Garnet-type electrolyte Solid composite electrolyte All-solid-state battery 1 Introduction To address energy crisis and increasing environmental pollution, wind, solar and geothermal energy have been paid much attention due to their clean and renewable characteristic. However, they also suffer from uneven geographical distribution and unstable energy supply. Therefore, highly efficient energy storage and conversion devices are really needed for them to better service our humans. Lithium ion batteries (LIBs) are one of good choices because they possess high operating voltage, high energy/power density, long cycle life and environmental friendless [1,2]. In recent years, LIBs have been developed rapidly and still have potential for further development, however, classical LIBs will soon reach their energy density limits because of the physico-chemical limitation (Fig. 1 (a)) [3]. Using lithium metal anode instead of other possible anodes is thought to be effective in increasing battery energy density, because lithium metal has the highest theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g–1), lowest electrochemical potential (–3.04 V vs. the standard hydrogen electrode) and lightweight (ρ= 0.53 g cm−3) [1,4,5]. However, currently, most of commercial available LIBs use liquid electrolytes where Li salts are dissolved in organic solvents, which brings potential safety hazard because these organic solvents are volatile, flammable and easy to leak [6]. More importantly, the growth of lithium dendrites and low Coulombic efficiency (CE) in liquid organic electrolytes prevent the direct application of lithium metal in practical LIBs [7–10]. In contrast, the use of solid electrolytes can not only enhance battery energy density, but also be expected to solve the safety problem, and thereby enabling the direct use of lithium metal as the anode in all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs). In ASSLBs, solid electrolytes not only need to provide efficient lithium ion conductive pathways, but also serve as the separator to prevent anode and cathode directly contact. Therefore, they should possess as high as possible ionic conductivity at room temperature, and at the same time, negligible electronic conductivity. Low electronic conductivity also contributes to an excellent battery performance for it can decrease the formation of lithium dendrite within solid electrolytes [11]. In addition, wide electrochemical window, good chemical/thermal stability, sufficient mechanical strength, high Li+ transference number, stable against to lithium metal, easy process and low cost are also the requirements for solid electrolytes' practical application [12]. Generally, solid electrolytes can be divided into three categories, including solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs) and organic-inorganic SCEs. Also, ISEs are classified into oxide-based, sulfide-based electrolytes, etc. [13]. Relative local properties of oxide, sulfide and polymer solid-state electrolytes are displayed in Fig. 1(b, c and d). Therein, oxides include crystalline NASICON-type ([LiM2(PO4)3, M = Ti, Ge, Zr, etc.], representative examples: LATP [Li1+ x Al x Ti2- x P3O12] and LAGP [Li1+ x Al x Ge2- x P3O12]), LISICON-type (Li2+2 x Zn1- x GeO4 and γ − Li 3 PO 4 ), perovskite-type (Li3 x La2/3- x TiO3), garnet-type compounds (Li x La3M2O12, M = Ta, Nb, Zr), and amorphous/glass group including Li2O-MO x (M = Si, B, P) and LiPON (Li x PO y N z ) materials [14]. Thanks to Ti4+ is easily reduced by lithium metal, Ti-containing solid electrolytes, such as Li1+ x Al x Ti2- x P3O12 and Li3 x La2/3- x TiO3, are unstable against lithium metal anode [15]. LAGP containing expensive Ge element results in a high cost; LISICON-type solid electrolytes exhibit comparative low ionic conductivity over other oxide-based solid electrolytes. In contrast, garnet-type Li7La3Zr2O12 and its derivatives (LLZO-based) show high ionic conductivity (10−4 to 10−3 S cm−1) at room temperature, negligible electronic transport, wide potential window range (0–4.5–9 V), good chemical stability against Li metal [16], and therefore they have emerged as one type of the most promising solid electrolyte materials for ASSLBs. Previous studies indicate LLZO has cubic (space group Ia-3d and I-43 d) and tetragonal (space group I41/acd) phases [17,18]. LLZO with cubic phase is thermodynamically unstable at room temperature and possesses two orders of magnitude higher ionic conductivity than tetragonal phase [19,20]. Super-valent cations, such as Al3+ and Ga3+, have been doped into cubic LLZO to enhance its room temperature stability [21,22]. Furthermore, multiple elements such as Nb5+ [23] and Ti4+ [24] have also been introduced into the crystal structure of LLZO to enhance the bulk ionic conductivity significantly. It is found that these element-doped LLZO possess ionic conductivity up to 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature and display excellent chemical stability over an extended temperature range. Nevertheless, ASSLBs assembled with pure LLZO-based solid electrolytes usually show poor battery performance. On the one hand, the lager interfacial resistance originated from inadequate electrode-electrolyte contact and the side reactions between the electrolytes and moisture/CO2 results in the poor battery performance [25]. On the other hand, the growth of lithium dendrite usually caused by charge/discharge at a large current density and/or long cycle also leads to the poor battery performance. Although LLZO-based materials have been considered to be able to suppress the growth of lithium dendrites well because of its high mechanical strength and high Li+ transference number, lithium dendrites have still been observed to grow through grain boundaries and interconnected pores within LLZO pellet due to the inhomogeneous electric field at the Li/LLZO contact interface [26]. The large impedance at electrode/electrolyte interface and grain boundaries, lithium dendrite growth and brittle nature of LLZO-based materials prevent their direct application in ASSLBs [27–30]. In contrast, SPEs show advantages of easy fabrication, low-cost, scaleability, mechanical flexibility and relatively stable against cathode/lithium metal, which make SPEs have been extensively explored for lithium batteries [31]. SPEs are usually composed of polymer host and lithium metal salt. The former contains electron donor groups which can play a coordination role for Li+, in which the number and stability of functional groups and the flexibility of molecular chain have an important influence on solid polymer dielectrics. It is reported that the cation transport in polymers is achieved by intra-chain diffusion, inter-chain hopping and chain diffusion with segmental motion [32]. Generally, high ionic conductivity is related to the chain diffusion with segmental motion of the polymers, and diminishes rapidly with the increasing crystallinity of polymer matrix and the decreasing of working temperature [33]. Compared with conventional liquid electrolytes, SPEs offer distinct features, including no leakage of electrolytes, low flammability and high safety. However, SPEs also exhibit some disadvantages such as comparatively low ionic conductivity and small Li+ transference number at room temperature, as well as narrow electrochemical stable window. These intrinsic charters make ASSLBs assembled by flexible SPEs can obtain intimate interfacial contact between electrodes and electrolyte but show poor electrochemical performance. Recent investigations indicate that the dispersion of inorganic fillers into polymer hosts can effectively decrease the crystallinity of polymers, and thus in turn increase the overall ionic conductivity of the final SCEs [34,35], which provides an effective route to prepare SCEs with enhanced mechanical properties, ionic conductivity and interfacial stability. The inorganic fillers can be inert ceramic fillers (such as Al2O3, SiO2, TiO2) [36,37] or active ionic conductors (such as Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP) [38,39], LLZO-based materials [16], Li0.33La0.557TiO3 (LLTO) [40–43], Li6PS5Cl [44], and Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS) [45,46]). Among them, LLZO-based materials as the fillers has become the research hotspot due to the so many advantages reported in the previous literatures [14,47–50]. Unlike inert ceramic fillers, LLZO-based fillers can provide freely movable active Li+ and additional Li+ conductive channel. More importantly, due to the high electrochemical stability of LLZO-based materials and their interactions with polymer matrix, the SCEs would exhibit a wider electrochemical stability window, higher mechanical strength, and better thermal stability compared to pure SPEs. Hence, the SCEs fabricated by dispersing LLZO-based fillers into polymers can effectively mitigate the disadvantages, while without obviously sacrificing the advantages of each respective material. Fig. 2 summarizes the merits and shortcomings of different types of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs. To date, many excellent review papers on solid electrolytes have been published [16,25,51–61], including polymers [54,55], garnet-type electrolytes [16,56,57], sulfides [58,59] and composite electrolytes [25,60,61]. However, most of these reviews are mainly focused on relative broad context, including the synthesis methods, intrinsic properties and/or the electrode/interface modification techniques of solid electrolytes, and applications in symmetrical and/or half cells. Since there are more complicated situations in practical ASSLBs than these symmetrical and/or half cells, the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stable window of the solid electrolytes will be greatly reduced. Therefore, it's not enough to only focus on the basic properties obtained from these symmetrical and half cells from the perspective of practical application of ASSLBs. Based on the previously reported results and developments of the LLZO-based/polymer SCEs, it can be predicted that these SCEs will be applied to ASSLBs sooner or later. Hence, the electrochemical performances of practical ASSLBs assembled by these SCEs are also very important and should be paid more attention. In this review, the intrinsic properties of the LLZO-based/polymer SCEs, including LLZO-based/PEO SCEs (LLZO-based/PEO SCEs with uniform dispersion of LLZO-based fillers and LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs) and LLZO-based/novel polymers SCEs, are summarized. Besides, comprehensive updates on their applications in ASSLBs are also presented. Finally, the perspectives based on our understanding for future research on LLZO-based/polymer SCEs are summarized. It is worthwhile pointing out that the LLZO-based/gel polymer composite electrolytes [62–65] will not be covered in this review. 2 LLZO-based/PEO SCEs 2.1 LLZO-based/PEO SCEs with uniform dispersion of LLZO fillers Among various polymer matrixes, PEO is considered to be one of the most promising polymer matrixes because of its low cost, ability to dissolve a wide variety of lithium salts and relatively high chemical/electrochemical stability [66]. To overcome the comparatively low ionic conductivity as well as small Li+ transference number of PEO-based SPEs originated from its crystalline domains at room temperature [67], uniform dispersion of LLZO and its derivatives into PEO matrix has been demonstrated a good strategy. In this section, discussions will focus on the effects of phase, particle size, filling amount and morphology of the LLZO-based fillers, the addition of plasticizer on the intrinsic properties of the final LLZO-based/PEO SCEs and the performances of some typical solid-state batteries assembled with these SCEs. In addition, some strategies for overcoming the interfacial contact and lithium dendrite problems to construct ASSLBs with improved electrochemical performances will also be discussed. For clarification and comparisons, the intrinsic characters of the recently reported LLZO-based/PEO SCEs and their corresponding ASSLBs' electrochemical performances are displayed in Table 1 . 2.1.1 LLZO-based fillers with cubic and tetragonal phases As early as 2003, garnet-type Li+ conductors with a formula of Li5La3M2O12 (M = Nb, Ta) in a cubic phase structure (space group: Ia 3 ¯ d) was reported by Weppner's group [68], which are stable against lithium metal, but show low ionic conductivity of ~10 −6 S cm−1 at room temperature. Several years later, cubic garnet Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) with relatively high ionic conductivity of ~10 − 4 S cm−1 was discovered by the same group [69]. It is noted that the cubic phase LLZO is only stabilized by the Al-dopant originated from the ceramic crucibles during the high-temperature calcination [20]. In the subsequent studies, it is found that LLZO has cubic and tetragonal phases with a space group of Ia-3d or I-43d and I41/acd [17,18], respectively, and their corresponding crystal structures are displayed in Fig. 3 (a and b). In the cubic LLZO (c-LLZO), there are two Li+ sites, one is the tetrahedral gap 24d (Li1), and the other is the twisted octahedral gap 96 h (Li2). The octahedron and tetrahedron are coplanar with each other, forming a three-dimensional network channel for lithium ion transmission [70]. In the tetragonal LLZO (t-LLZO), Li+ occupies three positions, namely the tetrahedral gap 8a (Li1), the two octahedral gaps 16f (Li2) and 32 g (Li3) [17]. It is difficult for Li+ to transfer between the adjacent sites due to the ordered Li+ positions and vacancies in t-LLZO [17], resulting in its two orders of magnitude lower ionic conductivity compared to c-LLZO at room temperature [69,71]. Inspired by this important result, further investigations of the garnet-type solid-state electrolytes in cubic phase have attracted a great deal of interest in very recent years. Incorporating garnet-type LLZO into polymer matrix can be traced back to 2015. For the first time, tetragonal Li7La3Zr2O12 solid electrolyte powder in submicron size was incorporated into a PEO matrix by Choi et al. [72]. Due to the synergistic effect of LLZO and PEO matrix, the SCE exhibits a maximum ionic conductivity of 4.42 × 10−4 S cm−1 (55 °C) at the t-LLZO filling content of 52.5 wt%. A cell of Li|composite membrane|LiNi0.6Co0.2Mn0.2O2 exhibits a discharge specific capacity of 166 mAh g−1 at 0.02 C and a high initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 87.8%, which are obviously improved compared to those of the two cells assembled by PEO-only membrane or 52.5 wt% Al2O3 filled composite membrane. Although the enhanced specific capacity and ICE are achieved using this SCE with high filling content of t-LLZO, the subsequent studies mainly focus on using c-LLZO as the fillers for the preparation of SCEs due to its intrinsic higher ionic conductivity than t-LLZO. As expected, SCEs with c-LLZO as the fillers show much improved ionic conductivity, and their corresponding solid-state batteries deliver obviously enhanced electrochemical performances [47,73,74]. For example, Chen et al. successfully fabricated a serial of LLZO/PEO membranes by incorporating different quantities of LLZO ceramic powders into PEO polymer matrix in 2017 [47]. Investigation results indicate that a maximum Li+ conductivity of 5.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 can be achieved in the LLZO/PEO SCE with an optimal LLZO concentration of 7.5 wt%. Thus, an all-solid-state battery of LiFePO4|LLZO/PEO|Li displays a maximum discharge capacity of 150.1 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, good cycling performance, and excellent rate capability under 60 °C. Another SCE (PEO-0.5LLZNO) prepared by incorporating 33.3 wt% of LLZNO (LLZNO = Li6.4La3Zr1.4Nb0.6O12) powder into PEO matrix exhibits high ionic conductivity of 1.4 × 10−3 S cm−1 and a wide electrochemical window range of 0 ~ 5.2 V at 60 °C. Also, a LiFePO4|PEO-0.5LLZNO|Li cell can deliver a high specific discharge capacity of 153 mAh g−1 and excellent capacity retention of 97% after 150 cycles at 0.5 C under 60 °C [74]. Very recently, He et al. prepared a SCE (GCPEM-20) by solution-casting method, which is consisted of PEO with large molecular weight of ~ 5 × 106, lithium perchlorate (LiClO4) and Li6.28Al0.24La3Zr2O12 (Al-LLZO) in a mass ratio of 8:1:2. The fabricated SCE exhibits a high Li+ conductivity of 4.4 × 10−4 S cm−1 and a stable electrochemical window of 4.5 V at 30 °C [73]. Accordingly, the specific discharge capacity of LiCoO2 in the LiCoO2|PEO8-LiClO4 + 20 wt% Al-LLZO|Li cell is up to 142 mAh g−1 at 0.06 C and 25 °C. It is noted that the LLZO-based/PEO SCEs have also been successfully used to assemble Li-S batteries. In 2018, Tao et al. used a SCE containing PEO as the host and Al3+/Nb5+ co-doped cubic Li7La3Zr2O12 (15 wt%) as the filler and a modified sulfur cathode to assemble a Li-S battery successfully [75]. Within the fabricated Li-S battery, the sulfur-based cathode constructed by using LLZO@C matrix and PEO binders can successfully reduce the interfacial resistance between the sulfur and the ion/electron conductive matrix. Benefiting from the synergistic role of the composite cathode and SCE, this Li-S battery can deliver attractive specific capacities of more than 900, 1210 and 1556 mAh g−1 at 37, 50 and 70 °C, respectively, and capacity retention of 98.7% after 90 cycles compared to the 10th cycle at 0.05 mA cm−2 and 37 °C. These strategies for rational design of SCEs and sulfur-base cathode provide an effective way toward high performance all-solid-state Li-S batteries [76,77]. 2.1.2 LLZO-based fillers with different particle sizes Although c-LLZO possesses higher ionic conductivity, the ionic transport properties are closely correlated with the chemical compositions and microstructures of polycrystalline solid electrolytes [15,78]. Research results indicate the particle size of LLZO, causing different type of microstructure at the solid electrolyte surface, would be crucial to the ionic transport properties and cycling life of solid electrolyte. It has also been demonstrated that the c-LLZO can be stabilized at room temperature in nanostructured form in very recent years [79]. Furthermore, LLZO in small grain size was found to be more air-stable and resistant to reaction with ambient CO2 and water vapor than LLZO in large grain size, because less surface Li2CO3 was formed on the surface of LLZO with small grain size under both short- and long-term exposure conditions [79]. In addition, the Al segregation at grain boundaries causes it depletion from the bulk in large-grained samples finally results in high interfacial resistance, low densification rates and bad cycling behavior [78,79]. Based on these findings, small LLZO particles are expected to be more suitable as the fillers for the preparation of LLZO-based/PEO SCEs. A systematic study of the effect of Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) with different particle sizes as the fillers on the ionic conductivity of the LLZTO/PEO SCEs was conducted by Zhang et al. in 2016 [80]. In this work, LLZTO particles with different sizes of ~ 40, ~ 400 nm and ~ 10 µm were incorporated into insulating PEO matrix to generate three types of LLZTO/PEO SCEs, without the addition of any other lithium salt. Compared to the PEO doped with other lithium salts, SCEs with pure PEO display better ability to suppress the lithium dendrite growth. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the ionic conductivity of the three SCEs increases obviously with the decrease of the particle sizes of LLZTO. In particular, the SCE incorporated with ~ 40 nm LLZTO as the filler exhibits the highest ionic conductivity of 2.1 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, which is larger than those of the LLZTO/PEO SCEs with the 400 nm (1.3 × 10−5 S cm−1) or 10 µm (3.8 × 10−6 S cm−1) LLZTO particles. The authors suggest that the improved ionic conductivity is mainly attributed to the smaller particles possess a relatively larger specific surface area, leading to the enhancement of coherent conductivity paths and facilitating the occurrence of percolation. These results also agree well with the nano-scale particles are more effective on the enhancement of ionic conductivity compared to the micro-scale ones in the electrolytes without PEO [78,79]. Because of the improved properties of the LLZTO/PEO SCE, two all-solid-state lithium batteries of LiFePO4|LLZTO/PEO|Li and LiFe0.15Mn0.85PO4|LLZTO/PEO|Li both display superior electrochemical performance, with the specific capacities of 153.3 and 132.1 mAh g−1 at 0.05 C, respectively, and capacity retention of 90% after 200 cycles at 0.1 C under 60 °C. It is worth noting that the two all-solid-state batteries assembled by the soft LLZTO/PEO membranes are flexible and bendable, making them very promising for application. Although the LLZTO/PEO SCEs display a wide stable potential window up to 4.7 V, the inevitable decomposition of the polymer would result in degraded stability of these membrane electrolytes at high working voltage with time. To overcome this challenge, an alternative polymer with higher stability is encouraged in future investigation. By using a similar strategy, Li et al. has prepared a PEO:Ga-LLZO (Ga-LLZO: Li6.25Ga0.25La3Zr2O12) SCE by dispersing 16 vol% Ga-LLZO nanoparticles into the PEO matrix very recently [81]. The fabricated SCE deliver an ionic conductivity of 7.2 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 30 °C, which value is around four orders of magnitude higher than that of pure PEO-based electrolyte. Considering that LLZO-based fillers acting as the solid plasticizers can reduce the crystallinity of the polymers, most of SCEs with LLZO-based fillers dispersed potentially display enhanced ionic conductivity than the pure SPEs. However, two contrary cases were reported one after another [82,83]. For one instance, Langer et al. reported a SCE consisting of 40 vol% cubic Li6.25Al0.25La3Zr2O12 (Al-doped LLZO) with particles size of around 5 µm and PEO20-LiClO4 matrix showed lower ionic conductivity compared to the pure PEO electrolyte [82]. The presence of an insulating Li2CO3 layer on the Al-doped LLZO surface and the diffusion of Li+ from Al-doped LLZO ceramic particles into PEO matrix are considered as the major reasons for accounting for the decreased Li+ conductivity. For another case, Keller et al. prepared a SCE containing 70 wt% of c-LLZO (D50 = 0.9 µm) and PEO15-LiTFSI matrix by a solvent-free processing [83]. Although superior compatibility with lithium metal was obtained, the as-prepared SCE exhibited low ionic conductivity when compared to the P(EO)15LiTFSI. The authors suggested that Li+ preferentially passes through the tortuous polymer matrix pathways within the SCE rather than through combined (ceramic-polymer) paths, resulting in the low ionic conductivity of the LLZO/PEO SCE. Based on the observation of unnecessary pores (see Fig. 3(e) and marked in Fig. 3(f)) generated among the large-sized LLZO particles within the SCEs, in our opinion, these two abnormal cases may be ascribed to the formed pores that hinder the conduction of Li+ in the SCEs. 2.1.3 LLZO-based fillers with different amount Depending on the amount of LLZO-based fillers in the LLZO-based/PEO SCEs, there are three types of SCEs, including “ceramic-in-polymer” (a SCE with higher polymer volume/mass ratio), “transitional state intermediate” (a SCE with almost equivalent mass ratio of polymer and LLZO-based fillers) and “polymer-in-ceramic” (a SCE with 10 ~ 20 wt% of polymer filled). Each SCE exhibits unique Li+ transfer routes, as illustrated by the schematic images listed in Fig. 4 (a), and finally shows uniquely intrinsic properties [50]. In the case of the “ceramic-in-polymer” SCEs, the low amount of LLZTO (LLZTO = Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12) fillers is not enough to form a connected Li+ conductive pathway, and thus Li+ is mainly transported through PEO matrix. With the increase of LLZTO fillers, the overall Li+ conductivities are provided by two transfer pathways, including both the PEO polymer and LLZTO ceramic fillers. Further increasing the amount of LLZTO fillers, the overall Li+ conductivities are mainly dominated by the LLZTO ceramic conductivity in the “polymer-in-ceramic” SCE. Using the optimal LLZTO filling amount, a “ceramic-in-polymer” SCE exhibiting the largest ionic conductivity of 1.17 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C was achieved [50]. This SCE was then used to assemble a LiFePO4|PEO8-LiTFSI-10 wt% LLZTO|Li solid state battery, which delivers high specific capacities of 148.6 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and high capacity retention of 93.6% after 100 cycles within a voltage range of 2.9–3.8 V at 55 °C (Fig. 4(d)). In contrast to the LiFePO4|PEO8-LiTFSI |Li cell, a more stable electrolyte/anode interface demonstrated by the smaller change value of the charge-transfer resistance and the less formation of Li dendrites can interpret the better cycle performance of the LiFePO4|PEO8-LiTFSI-10 wt% LLZTO|Li cell. In addition, another solid-state LiFePO4|Li battery assembled with a “polymer-in-ceramic” SCE (PEO-LLZTO-PEG-60 wt% LiTFSI) can deliver an initial discharge capacity of 122.5 mAh g−1 with a high Coulombic efficiency of 99.2% and excellent capacity retention of 103.6% after 50 cycles within a voltage range of 2.6–4.0 V (Fig. 4(e)), indicating excellent stable electrode/electrolyte interfaces during the cycling process. All these results indicate both the “ceramic-in-polymer” and “polymer-in-ceramic” SCEs can be applied to assemble solid-sate lithium batteries with excellent electrochemical performances. Based on the systematical investigation and comprehensive consideration of the properties (ionic conductivity, flexibility and thermal stability) of the SCEs and their corresponding cells, two important points should be point out herein. For one thing, ceramic-based SCE with high amounts of LLZTO fillers can improve battery performance at high temperatures owing to it possesses good thermal stability without a noticeable shrinkage up to 140 °C. For another thing, the “polymer-in-ceramic” SCE is more suitable for a large battery because of its higher mechanical strength and thermal stability, while the “ceramic-in-polymer” SCE with a greater flexibility and lower cost is more appropriate for small-scale flexible energy storage devices [50]. In the study of LLZO-based/PEO SCEs, researchers always want to obtain a SCE with maximum ionic conductivity, excellent mechanical properties, good thermal stability and stable electrochemical performance by optimizing the filling content of LLZO-based particles [47,50,84]. Generally, the SCE with high LLZO amount shows good thermal stability and enhanced ionic conductivity [85], although the particle size of LLZO [15], the Li salts (LiTFSI/LiClO4/LiPF6/LiBOB) [86] and ether oxygen to lithium ion molar ratio [87] play some positive or negative effect on the optimal filling amount. It is worth noting that the “polymer-in-ceramic” SCE with high volume and/or mass ratio of LLZO generally results in the heterogeneous dispersion of the LLZO particles (especially LLZO particles in nano-scale), because the LLZO particles tent to form clusters to reduce their surface free energy. In addition, the big gap in the surface energy between nano-LLZO and PEO also leads to poor contact between them. Both of them would block the Li+ conductive pathways and therefore reduce the ionic conductivity [47,50,85]. To circumvent these problems, two ways to improve interfacial wetting between nano-LLZTO and PEO were proposal. One method is to introduce an interfacial layer which has good compatibility with both materials. For example, the dopamine with dual wetting capability on both organic and inorganic materials was coated on the surface of LLZTO to allow 80 wt% of LLZTO to be uniformly dispersed in 20 wt% PEO/LiTFSI polymer electrolyte [85]. As a result, a SCE with increased ionic conductivity of 1.1 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, decreased interfacial resistance, superior thermal stability and electrochemical performance was successfully prepared. Because of the good electrode/electrolyte interfacial contact, a solid-state LiFePO4|LLZTO@PDA/PEO|Li cell can deliver a discharge capacity of 142.6 mAh g−1, and high capacity retention of 99.6% after 50 cycles at 0.2 C and 50 °C. The other way is to develop a simple and efficient interface engineering. For instance, Zha et al. prepared a SCE containing 90 wt% LLZTO powder and 10 wt% PEO18-LiTFSI through wet coating and hot pressing technique [88]. After hot pressing, the ionic conductivity of 90LLZTO-10PEO18 electrolyte can be significantly increased from 6.39 × 10−4 mS·cm−1 to 4.26 × 10−3 at 30 °C, and it can even reach to 2.17 × 10−2 mS cm−1 at 60 °C. These results suggest that continuous and homogeneous structure formed by hot pressing contributes to the enhanced ionic conductivity, which provide an alternative method to prepare SCEs and construct ASSLBs with improved performance. Accordingly, the assembled LiFePO4/90LLZTO-10PEO18/Li cell exhibited a maximum discharge specific capacity of 151.6 mAh g−1 and maintained high capacity retention of 97.8% after 50 cycles at 0.1 C and 60 °C. 2.1.4 LLZO-based fillers with different morphologies Uniformly dispersing nano/micron-sized LLZO-based ceramic particles into PEO matrix can improve the ionic conductivity of the SCE through reducing the crystallinity of PEO and enhancing the percolation effect between PEO and LLZO-based ceramic filler. Considering that the much higher ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability of LLZO-based fillers, theoretically, the more the amount of LLZO in the SCE, the higher its overall performance should be. However, excessive LLZO fillers would agglomerate and introduce some pores into polymer matrix [84,89], leading to decreased ionic conductivity. In addition, uniformly and randomly dispersed ceramic particles cannot generate a long-range and continuous pathway for Li+ transportation. Therefore, Li+ transferred through PEO matrix will be blocked by the isolated LLZO particles. In contrast, using LLZO with unique morphology as the fillers, such as 1-D nanofiber [90] and nanowire [91], 3-D framework [92–96] and 2-D nanosheet [97], can not only provide interconnected and continuous Li+ conductive pathways, but also solve the problem of the agglomeration of LLZO in high mass/volume loadings. Benefiting from these advantages, LLZO with these unique morphologies are more effectively in enhancing ionic conductivity and mechanical strength compared with nano/micro-sized particle counterparts due to following reasons: (i) by forming interconnected and continuous Li+ conductive pathways in LLZO phase thus greatly enhance the ionic conductivity, which is difficult to obtain in the SCE with nanoparticles uniformly and randomly dispersed; (ii) The highly conductive interface formed through the percolating effect between polymers and LLZO is interconnected and continuous, thus facilitating the transportation of Li+; and (iii) the 3-D framework enables the LLZO filler up to a high content without agglomeration, which is not only beneficial to enhance the ionic conductivity, but also makes the SCEs possess high mechanical strength, better thermal and electrochemical stability. Table 2 summarizes the intrinsic properties of PEO SCEs containing LLZO-based fillers in different morphologies and their applications in ASSLBs. For the first time, Fu et al. prepared a SCE with high mechanical strength and ionic conductivity by directly soaking a 3-D LLZO (Li6.4La3Zr2Al0.2O12) nanofiber networks into Li salt–polymer solutions in 2016 [90]. The used 3-D LLZO porous structure consisted of randomly distributed and interconnected nanofibers was synthesized by electrospinning route in combination with high temperature calcination in air. As expected, the as-prepared flexible SCE exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 2.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature, good thermal stability and a wide electrochemical stable window. What's more, the fabricated electrolyte membrane shows stable cycle time up to 500 and 300 h at the current densities of 0.2 and 0.5 mA cm−2, respectively, exhibiting excellent lithium dendrites suppressing performance. To further explore the advantages of LLZO nanowires in the improvement of ionic conductivity and the suppression of lithium dendrite growth, He's group has prepared a composite electrolyte (PPLN) using PEO with lithium bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl)imide (LITFSI) as the matrix and LLZO nanowires as fillers and then assembled an actual LiFePO4/PLLN/Li battery, as shown in Fig. 5 (a) [91]. In their innovation work, PEO-LITFSI used as both binder of cathode and the matrix of the composite electrolyte can be fused at high temperature to form an integrated structure (Fig. 5(b)). With this configuration, the ionic conductivity of PPLN composite electrolyte was improved, the interfacial impedance between the composite electrolyte and cathode was greatly reduced, and the ionic transportation inside the composite cathode was accelerated. Thus, the integrated LiFePO4/PLLN/Li battery shows outstanding electrochemical performance, with a high specific discharge capacity of 158.8 mAh g−1 after 70 cycles at 0.5 C under 60 °C (Fig. 5(c)) and a specific discharge capacity of 158.7 mAh g−1 after 80 cycles at 0.1 C under 45 °C (Fig. (5d)). This simple and effective method for assembling an all-solid-state battery with integration structure is desirable. The above-mentioned LLZO-based nanofibes/nanowires as fillers can obviously enhance the mechanical properties and electrochemical performance of the SCEs, which stimulate the researchers to prepare LLZO-based materials with other unique morphologies (3-D interconnected structure [38,92-96], 2-D nanosheets [97]) by using novel method and further explore their contributions to the improvement of the performances for the SCEs. For example, to avoid the filler concentration limitation caused by the agglomeration of nanofillers, LLZO with 3-D interconnected and porous structure fabricated by using hydrogels as the template was filled with PEO-LiTFSI to get the composite electrolyte (3-d-CPE) [92]. The synthesized 3-d-CPE with 62 wt% LLZO provides long-range and continuous lithium ion pathway, which makes the 3-d-CPE show enhanced ionic conductivity of 8.5 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 25 °C and ~ 10−3 S cm−1 at 60 °C, and improved electrochemical/thermal stability as well as interfacial stability. A solid-state LiFePO4|3-d-CPE|Li battery can deliver high specific discharge capacity of 158 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and good rate performance, with 101 mAh g−1 at 2 C under 60 °C. Based on these positive results, it is suggested that the use of hydrogel as the template may provide the possibility for large scale fabrication of LLZO with 3-D structures for next-generation solid-state electrolytes. In order to achieve a SCE membrane consisting of cubic LLZO interconnected network and PEO-LiTFSI polymer in low-cost, Hu's group designed a facile and large scalable strategy in 2018 [93]. During the synthesis procedures, they firstly used bacteria cellulose (BC) as the template to absorb the relevant precursor salt solution to generate porous cubic-phase garnet-type LLZO nanofiber 3-D network after heat treatment, and then infiltrated the PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte into the as-prepared LLZO nanofiber network to form a SCE with improved flexibility, high ionic conductivity of 1.12 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature and a wide stable voltage window up to 6.0 V vs. Li/Li+. By using a similar strategy reported by Hu's group, Li et al. reported a cheap morphogenetic route for the preparation of hierarchically nanostructured 3-D garnet-type LLZO monoliths [94]. Firstly, a 3-D macroporous interconnected LLZO material was prepared by using degreasing cotton as the sacrifice template, and then immersed in a precursor solution containing PEO and LiTFSI lithium salt to finally fabricate the composite electrolyte membrane (Fig. 6 (a)). The prepared SCE exhibited an enhanced Li+ conductivity of 8.9 × 10−5 S cm−1 at room temperature and a wide electrochemical stable window up to 5.5 V. The fabricated LiFePO4|LLZO/PEO-LiTFSI|Li battery remains nearly 100% capacity retention capability over 50 cycles at 0.2 C and 30 °C. Moreover, it delivers high rate capacities of 160.8 and 120.7 mAh g−1 at 0.1 and 1.0 C, respectively. Next, two SCEs with 3-D garnet fillers showing an enhanced ionic conductivities of 1.2 × 10−4 [95] and 2.25 × 10−5 S cm−1 [96] at 30 °C as well as improved thermal, mechanical, and electrochemical stabilities (Fig. 6(b and c)) were fabricated in succession, where the 3-D LLZO-based fillers were prepared by the template route using polymer sponge and cleanroom wipers as templates, respectively. So many successful examples shown herein to demonstrate the preparation of 3D LLZO-based materials by using the template route and then used to construct 3-D garnet SCEs provide a promising prospect for fabricating other types of high performance SCEs in the future. Meanwhile, it also should be noted that the as-prepared 3-D LLZO/PEO SCEs display some differences in Li+ conductivity, stable electrochemical window, and electrochemical performance in their corresponding ASSLBs, suggesting that further investigations are still needed to improve the properties of 3-D LLZO/PEO SCEs. In contrast to the LLZO-based materials in 1-D and 3-D structures for constructing the PEO-based SCEs, 2-D LLZO nanosheets are rarely reported. Very recently, Song et al. have been successfully synthesized garnet nanosheets by coprecipitation with graphene oxide (GO) template for the first time [97]. The garnet nanosheets with interconnected structure were incorporated into hybrid PEO−LiClO4−EmimFSI matrix for fabricating a SCE with continuous Li+ transport pathway and structural robustness. The fabricated SCE with 15 wt% garnet nanosheet displays high ionic conductivity of 3.6 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25 °C and can robustly isolate Li dendrites in a symmetric battery upon reversible cycling at 0.1 mA cm−2 over 200 h under 40 °C. Although this SCE possesses the highest Li+ conductivity up to now, the LiFePO4|Li cell assembled by this SCE does not exhibit the best electrochemical performance compared to previously reported ASSLBs, with an initial discharge capacity of only 98.1 mAh g−1 at 0.05 C under 40 °C. 2.1.5 The effect of plasticizers on LLZO-based/PEO SCEs The use of liquid and/or solid plasticizers can further improve the overall performance of the SCEs. On the one hand, plasticizers can effectively enhance ionic conductivity by reducing the crystallinity of polymers. On the other hand, the addition of plasticizers can improve the plasticity and viscosity of the SCEs, leading to decreased interfacial resistance by facilitating interfacial contact between the SCEs and the electrodes [98]. In particular, plasticizer can provide several pathways for Li+ transport. In view of the advantages of LLZO-based fillers and plasticizers, investigation of the synergistic effects of LLZO-based fillers and plasticizers on the intrinsic properties of SCEs and the electrochemical performance of their corresponding ASSLBs are of great importance [49,99-101]. In order to further increase the ionic conductivity without at the expense of mechanical strength and safety of the PEO-based SCEs, Chen and his co-workers studied the effects of different amounts of succinonitrile (SN) as the solid plasticizer on the properties of LLZTO/PEO (LLZTO = Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12) SCE [49,99]. It is found that the addition of SN can enhance the plasticity, viscosity and ionic conductivity of the SCE, which thus improves the interfacial contact between the electrolytes and the electrode [99]. Therefore, a SCE consisting of 60 wt% LLZTO and 10 wt% SN was successfully prepared, which possesses high ionic conductivity of 1.22 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C, larger Li+ transference number of 0.41 and a wide electrochemical stability window (> 5.5 V). By using this good SCE, a solid-state LiFePO4|Li battery can deliver high discharge capacity of 151.9 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C under 60 °C, superior rate performance (126.1 mAh g−1 at 1 C), and excellent capacity retention of 98.0% at 0.5 C after 200 cycles. Even at a lower temperature of 45 °C, the battery still delivers a discharge capacity of 124.1 mAh g−1 after 70 cycles at 0.5 C. In a very recent work reported by Xie et al., tetrabutylphosphonium 2-hydroxypyridine (TBPHP) ionic liquid was used to further improve the performance of composite electrolyte consisting of PEO8-LiTFSI matrix and 12.5 wt% LLZTO fillers [100]. The synergistic effect of TBPHP ionic liquid and LLZTO makes the composite electrolyte exhibit excellent performance, including a high ionic conductivity of 9.39 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 50 °C, a wide electrochemical stable window up to 5.0 V and a high Li+ ion transference number of 0.63. A LiFePO4|Li battery with this composite electrolyte delivers discharge capacity of ~149.6 mAh g−1 and maintain ~100% capacity retention after 100 cycles at 0.2 C under 50 °C. More importantly, a pouch cell with this composite electrolyte can still work well even after several bending and cutting. It should be noted that a SCE (abbreviated LLZTO@IL/PEO) has been successfully fabricated [101], which is composed of Li-salt-free PEO and Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 nanoparticles interfacially wetted by an ionic liquid of ([BMIM]TF2N) as the plasticizer. Compared with the LLZTO/PEO electrolyte without the addition of [BMIM]TF2N, the LLZTO@IL/PEO shows higher conductivity, a large electrochemical window, lower activated energy and decreased interface impedance at 20 °C, enabling the LiFePO4|LLZTO@IL/PEO|Li and LiFe0.15Mn0.85PO4|LLZTO@IL/PEO|Li batteries both work well at 25 °C. 2.1.6 Interfacial contact and lithium dendrite issues In addition to high ionic conductivity at room temperature, robust mechanical strength to suppress lithium dendrite growth and high chemical/electrochemical stability against Li metal, and an ideal interface between the solid electrolyte and electrode are also very important for ASSLBs to achieve a high performance [102]. Cheng et al. studied the performances of an all-solid-state LiFePO4|Li battery with a composite electrolyte membrane composed of uniformly distributed Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) fillers in PEO/LiClO4 matrix at various charge-discharge rates and temperatures [103]. Results show that the temperature plays very key role in the electrochemical performance of an ASSLB, that is, a LiFePO4|Li battery with a LLZTO/PEO composite electrolyte (30.1 wt% of LLZTO) can deliver a high specific capacity of > 150 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, good rate performance (~ 80 mAh g−1 at 4 C) and excellent capacity retention of 83% after 500 cycles at 1 C at 60 °C. However, this ASSLB is unable to work well at 30 °C owing to the low ionic conductivity and high electrode/electrolyte interfacial resistance [103]. Furthermore, this phenomenon becomes worse if the cathode contains high mass loading of active materials. Thus, an advanced technology for assembling practical bulk-type ASSLBs to overcome the interfacial issues caused by the low working temperature is urgently needed. In 2017, Chen et al. [104] proposed and demonstrated a synergistic all-composite approach to fabricating flexible ASSLBs with high surface capacity and energy density. In this work, PEO-based composite cathode layers (filled with LiFePO4 particles) and composite electrolyte layers (PEO filled with Al-LLZTO particles) are stacked layer-by-layer with lithium foils as negative layer firstly, and then hot-pressed into a monolithic all-solid-state lithium battery. By using this novel strategy, both mesoscopic and microscopic interfaces inside the all-solid-state battery are improved, and thus the all-composite bulk-type lithium battery, assembling by a composite electrolyte (60 wt% Al-LLZTO in PEO matrix), LiFePO4 cathode with 15 wt% PEO and Li foil anode, can deliver a high specific discharge capacity of 155 mAh g−1 (100 µA cm−2) and high capacity retention of ~100% after 10 cycles at 60 °C. Also, this all-composite approach may provide a new toolbox for achieving low interfacial impedance within other ASSLBs. Another strategy for addressing the low ionic conductivity and high electrode/electrolyte interfacial resistance at low and/or room temperatures was developed by Falco et al. They used a supersoft poly(ethylene oxide)/tetraglyme (G4)/LiTFSI as the matrix, cubic garnet LLZO as the fillers and a photoinitiator to prepare the SCE by cross-linked reaction under UV-light [105]. Due to the highly amorphous solid polymer electrolytes achieved from the cross-linking of PEO encompassing low-vapor-pressure tetraglyme, SCE exhibits high ionic conductivity exceeding 0.1 mS cm−1 at 20 °C, An all-solid-state LiFePO4|Li battery assembled by this SCE can work well at subambient (10 °C), ambient (21 °C) and moderately high (40 °C) temperatures, with high specific capacity, superior rate performance and long cycle stability. Inhomogeneous Li plating/stripping results in the growth of lithium dendrite, leading to battery short circuit, catch fire and even explosion [106]. Generally, a composite electrolyte with large Li+ transference number (close to unit) contributes to uniform Li plating/stripping, and thus can effectively suppress the growth of lithium dendrites. Therefore, the preparation of a composite electrolyte with large Li+ transference number is encouraged. Very recently, Zhao et al. has successfully fabricated a flexible anion-immobilized Al-LLZTO/PEO SCE with Li ion transference number as high as 0.58 to inhibit lithium dendrites and construct safe ASSLBs [107]. In this SCE, anions are tethered by PEO matrix and ceramic fillers, inducing a uniform distribution of space charges and Li+ that contributes to a dendrite-free lithium deposition. The SCE with 40% Al-LLZTO content shows a preferable ionic conductivity of 1.12 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 25 °C, and a stable voltage window high up to 5.5 V. All-solid-state LiFePO4|Li cell with this anion-immobilized SCE delivers a high discharge specific capacity of ~ 155 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C under 60 °C and good cycling performance with only 13% capacity fade after 100 cycles. The development of an anion-immobilized SCE may be a promising opportunity for next-generation safe and flexible ASSLBs. 2.2 LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs In the case of uniformly incorporating LLZO-based ceramic fillers into polymer matrix, the properties of the as-prepared SCEs are mainly dominated by the polymers unless the ceramic fillers are up to a high concentration. In addition to serving as solid plasticizers, LLZO-based fillers provide only a small amount of freely moveable Li+ as well as Li+ channels in these SCEs [25]. Solid-state batteries with these SCEs can only exhibit satisfactory discharge specific capacities and cycle performance at low C-rate and/or high operating temperatures. Differently, solid-state batteries with only LLZO-based ceramics as the electrolytes can achieve excellent rate performance and be compatible with high voltage cathode materials due to LLZO-based ceramics possess high ionic conductivity at room temperature and wide electrochemical stable windows [16,19]. However, the high rigidity of both LLZO-based ceramic electrolytes and electrodes materials results in poor physical contact and inadequate wettability between electrolytes and electrodes, leading to high interfacial resistance, terrible Li-ion diffusion and large overpotential [16,108–110]. In addition, the growth of lithium dendrites within LLZO-based electrolytes originated from the inhomogeneous current distribution also hinders their direct applications in practical ASSLBs. To solve these above-mentioned issues, especially for lithium dendrite growth and poor interfacial contact with electrodes, introducing interfacial layer has been considered as an effective strategy [16,111]. Inspired by the pioneer work of Goodenough's group on using a polymer/ceramic membrane/polymer sandwich electrolyte to construct an all-solid-state battery that can deliver a superb long term electrochemical stability and a high coulombic efficiency [112], some LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs, including “PEO/LLZO-based ceramics” bilayer electrolyte [113], “PEO/LLZO-based ceramics/PEO” sandwich electrolyte [114], “PEO-LLZO composite layer/LLZO/PEO-LLZO composite layer” sandwich electrolyte [115] and “PEO-LLZO composite thin layer/PEO-LLZO composite layer/PEO-LLZO composite thin layer” sandwich electrolyte (PEO-LLZO composite thin layer is“ceramic-in-polymers” and PEO-LLZO composite layer is “polymer-in-ceramics”) [116], have been developed. Within these layered SCEs, PEO polymer shows three significant roles: 1) PEO serving as a buffer layer to tolerate volume expansion of the electrode during cycling and thus maintain better contact with the electrolyte and electrodes; 2) PEO acting as a wetting layer to increase the contact area with electrodes and decrease interfacial impedance and 3) PEO as a buffer layer to suppress lithium dendrite growth due to its better mechanical strength and it can prevent the direct contact between Li metal anode and LLZO-based ceramics. Table 3 summarizes the ionic conductivity of the recently reported LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs and their applications in ASSLBs. Li et al. designed an all-solid-state LiFePO4/LLZTO-2LiF/CPEO/Li battery (LLZTO = Li6.5La3Zr1.5Ta0.5O12; CPEO = cross-linked polyethylene oxide-LiTFSI polymer) in 2017 [113], in which CPEO with a melting point of 240 °C works as the buffer layer to suppress the Li-dendrite growth. The LiFePO4 cathode was mixed with the CPEO-LITFSI polymer to decrease the interfacial resistance between LLZTO-2LiF electrolyte and LiFePO4. Thus, this all-solid-state battery exhibits low overpotential of 0.2 V at 80 µA cm−2, high initial discharge capacity of 142 mAh g−1 (80 µA cm−2) and good capacity retention of 84.51% after 100 cycles at 80 µA cm−2 under 65 °C. The first “PEO/LLZO-based ceramics/PEO” sandwich-type electrolyte was reported by Fan's group in 2019 [114], based on the design concept for sandwich-type electrolyte using other polymers [111,117]. Firstly, SPE precursor solution containing PEO (M w 100,000) and LiTFSI in acetonitrile with O/Li mole ratio of 8:1 was quantificationally dripped onto the surface of LLZTO (Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12) ceramic disk with burette and dried to achieve a “PEO-LLZTO-PEO” electrolyte. Then the as-prepared electrolyte was used to assemble all-solid-state batteries of Li|PEO-LLZTO-PEO|Li, 3-D|PEO-LLZTO-PEO|3D-Li and LiFePO4|PEO-LLZTO-PEO|3D-Li. After introducing the soft PEO buffer layer, a continuous contact between LLZTO solid-state electrolyte and solid electrodes was maintained, as shown in Fig. 6(d). However, the Li|PEO-LLZTO-PEO|Li cell shows an extremely unstable overpotential voltage which firstly increases and then fluctuates, and finally drop to 0 V and remain unchanged after 140 cycles at a current of 0.2 mA cm−2 under 90 °C. This abrupt voltage drop caused by overmuch Li dendrites piercing through the electrolyte can be overcome by the 3-D Li electrodes, as illustrated in Fig. 6(e). Benefitting from this design, the 3-D|PEO-LLZTO-PEO|3D-Li cell exhibits a stable voltage profile over 700 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 under 90 °C and maintains dendrite-free 3D Li anodes after cycling. Meanwhile, the LiFePO4|PEO-LLZTO-PEO|3D-Li cell also shows a stable cycling performance at 0.2 C under 90 °C, with a specific capacity of 135 mAh g−1 and a high coulombic efficiency of ~99.6% after 200 cycles. These results suggest that other factors should be considered for fabricating high energy and safe all-solid-state batteries, except for using solid electrolytes with good properties. PEO filling with LLZO-based ceramics serving as the buffer layers to further improve the electrochemical performance and interfacial contact as well as suppress lithium dendrite growth have also been reported very recently. For example, the symmetric Li|PEO-LLBNZO|LLBNZO|PEO-LLBNZO|Li (LLBNZO = Li6.5La2.5Ba0.5NbZrO12) cell shows four times smaller charge transfer resistance than the symmetric Li|LLBNZO|Li cell, exhibiting stable and reversible Li plating/stripping for more than 140 h at high current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 under 35 °C [115]. After detail investigation on the composite electrolytes from “ceramic-in-polymer” (CIP) to “polymer-in-ceramic” (PIC) with different sizes of garnet particles for dendrite suppression effect, Sun's group constructed a sandwich-type composite electrolyte (SCE) with hierarchical garnet particles (a PIC-5 µm interlayer sandwiched between two CIP-200 nm thin layers, where PIC-5 µm is a PEO-based composite electrolyte with 80 vol% 5 µm LLZTO and CIP-200 nm is PEO-based composite electrolyte with 20 vol% 200 nm LLZTO) in 2019, as shown in Fig. 7 (a) [116]. This novel composite electrolyte can simultaneously suppress dendrite growth and possess excellent interfacial contact with Li metal, with highly stable Li plating/stripping cycling for over 400 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 at 30 °C. An all-solid-state LiFePO4|SCE|Li cell exhibits good rate performance, with specific capacities of 118.6 and 63.2 mAh g−1 at 0.1 and 0.5 C, respectively, and high capacity retention of 82.4% after 200 cycles at 0.1 C and 30 °C. This design of sandwich-type composite electrolytes using hierarchical fillers is a promising strategy to fabricate dendrite-free solid-state batteries with high energy density at room temperature. It is worth noting that the thickness of the polymer buffer layer is very important to simultaneously achieve high ionic conductivity without hindering Li+ transport, good mechanical strength to suppress the growth of Li dendrites, as well as good contact with the electrodes. In addition to the above-discussed PEO-based polymers, some other compounds such as pure metal [118], metal alloys [119], lithiated Si [120], metal oxides [121], boron nitride nanosheets [122] and lithium–graphite (Li-C) [123] have also been used as the buffer layers to achieve lithium dendrite suppression and excellent interfacial contact simultaneously. 3 LLZO-based/novel polymers SCEs Based on general discussion on the above-mentioned ASSLBs assembled by LLZO-based/PEO SCEs, it is found that most of them have to work at elevated temperatures (~ 50 °C) to achieve favorable comprehensive electrochemical performances. This is because the SCEs can deliver decent ionic conductivity, suitable Li+ transference number as well as acceptable electrode/electrolyte interfacial resistance only at such high temperatures. However, the PEO would be in a quasi-molten state (or a gel state) and thus lose its original mechanical properties in these working temperatures because of its low melting point of ~ 65 °C, which results in the invalid lithium dendrites suppression and potential safety hazard [124,125]. In addition, quasi-molten state PEO can gradually diffuse across the porous SEI layer and leads to an endless loss of lithium from the cathode, resulting in bad electrochemical cycle performance [112]. Meanwhile, PEO shows high viscosity, poor film-forming ability as well as narrow electrochemical window, which further hinder the LLZO-based/PEO SCEs for large scale application in real batteries. To explore LLZO-based/polymer SCEs with better properties, other novel types of polymers, such as poly(propylene carbonate) (PPC) [125–128], poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) [129–132], poly(vinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) [133–137], poly(ethylene carbonate) (PEC) [138], polyacrylonitrile (PAN) [139], poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) [140], cross-linked polyethyleneglycol [141], poly(ethylene glycol) diacrylate (PEGDA) [142] and mixed polymers [143–145] have been developed as the substrate for constructing novel LLZO-based/polymer SCEs. Table 4 summarizes the intrinsic properties of the typical LLZO-based/novel polymer SCEs and the electrochemical performances of ASSLBs assembled by these novel SCEs. PPC with high melting temperature up to 180 °C, high ionic conductivity and lithium ion transference number at room temperature is usually severed as the polymer matrix for solid state electrolytes. As early as 2015, Cui's group developed a new class of PPC-based solid polymer electrolyte (CPPC-SPE ) with safety-reinforced, wide voltage window of 4.6 V and high ionic conductivity at room temperature, by using PPC, LiTFSI and flame-retardant cellulose nonwoven membrane as raw materials [125]. It was successfully used to assemble an all-solid-state LiFePO4|CPPC-SPE|Li battery, which exhibits both superior rate capability and excellent electrochemical stable performance in a wide temperature range from 5 to 120 °C. By using the PPC-LiTFSI as the host material, they prepared some free-standing LLZTO/PPC (LLZTO = Li6.75La3Zr1.75Ta0.25O12) SCEs with different LLZTO filler amount for flexible solid-state lithium batteries in 2017 [126]. These SCEs can work well in a wide temperature range from 0 to 160 °C, as shown in Fig. 7(b and c). Specifically, a LLZTO/PPC SCE with 5 wt% LLZTO fillers displayed excellent comprehensive performance such as high ionic conductivity of 5.2 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 20 °C, a wide electrochemical window of 4.6 V, large Li+ transference number of 0.75 and satisfactory mechanical strength (6.8 MPa). In contrast, the ionic conductivity and Li+ transference number of the PPC-SPE without LLZTO fillers at the same temperature are only 3.9 × 10−4 S cm−1 and 0.60, respectively. Because of the intrinsic superior properties of this SCE, a flexible LiFePO4|LLZTO/PPC|Li4Ti5O12 battery can deliver excellent rate capability and superior cycling stability, with specific capacities of 123.0 and 80 mAh g−1 at 0.1 and 5 C, respectively, and 95% capacity retention after 800 cycles at 1 C under 20 °C. Similarly, another LLZTO/PPC SCE with ~ 11.8 wt%LLZTO prepared by Huo et al. in 2018 also displayed high ionic conductivity of 4.2 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature [127]. Furthermore, this SCE can be well compatible with Si electrode. It is found that an all-solid-state LiFePO4|LLZTO/PPC|Si cell shows excellent performance, with a discharge capacity of 2677 mAh g−1 in terms of Si anode, as well as capacity retention of 82.6% after 100 cycles at 0.1 C under 25 °C. Very recently, Chen et al. has fabricated a LLZO/PPC SCE membrane with 20 wt% Ta-doped LLZTO fillers, and then applied graphite-functionalized layers on the surfaces of the cathode and LLZO/PPC membrane, respectively, to assemble a solid NCM622|LLZTO/PPC|Li battery (Fig. 7(d and e)) [128]. In this cell, the graphite-functionalized layer can improve the compatibility between lithium anode and electrolyte, while the SCE layer on the NCM622 cathode can enhance the ionic conductivity and interfacial contact between cathode and electrolyte. With this battery configuration, the NCM622|LLZTO/PPC|Li battery can exhibit good comprehensive electrochemical performances, with an initial discharge capacities of 162.0 and 130.1 mAh g−1 at 1 and 3 C, respectively, and capacity retention of 77.3% after 150 cycles at 3 C under room temperature, although the used LLZTO/PPC SCE shows moderate ionic conductivity of 1.57 × 10−4 S cm−1. Similar to the concept of the asymmetric structure design of electrolytes, Sun's groupreported a rigid-flexible asymmetric solid electrolyte (ASE) that was successfully used in building ASSLBs [146]. The ASE efficiently suppresses the growth of lithium dendrites and enables the LiFePO4|ASE|Li cell with good cycle performance because of the hierarchical structure of a combination of “polymer-in ceramic” (rigid ceramic layer of Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12, which is close to Li anode) and “LiBOB in-polymer” (soft polymer-layer of polyethylene oxide and LiBOB components, which is close to cathode). PVDF has become another commonly used polymer matrix in composite electrolytes very recently. Compared with PEO, PVDF is more effective in dissociating lithium salt due to its high polarization and dielectric constant, making it more suitable be used in composite electrolytes to some extent [67]. Furthermore, PVDF possesses good electrochemical stability, much better thermal as well as mechanical properties than PEO [54]. Recently, PVDF-based SCEs with inert ceramic particles such as SiO2 and TiO2 have been studied and exhibit enhanced mechanical properties but still unsatisfactory ionic conductivities [67]. To prepare higher performance SCEs using PVDF-based as matrix, dispersing active LLZO-based ceramic fillers into this matrix has received a lot of attention. In 2017, Zhang et al. synthesized flexible CPEs membranes (LLZTO/PVDF-CPEs) composed of PVDF matrix and LLZTO (Li6.75La3Zr1.75Ta0.25O12) fillers by using a solution-casting method for the first time [129]. By the Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), Raman, and 1H NMR spectra and first-principles calculations, it is suggested that La atom of LLZTO can complex with the N atom and C = O group of solvent molecules as well as electrons enriching at the N atom, which behaves like a Lewis base and induces the chemical dehydrofluorination of the PVDF skeleton. Furthermore, partially modified PVDF chains activate the interactions between the PVDF matrix, lithium salt and LLZTO fillers, thus resulting in obviously enhanced performance of the LLZTO/PVDF-CPEs, with a high ionic conductivity of ~ 5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25 °C, high mechanical strength, and good thermal stability. The solid-state LiCoO2|LLZTO/PVDF-CPEs|Li battery can deliver minor polarization, excellent rate performance and cycling stability at 25 °C, with specific capacities of 145 and 130 mAh g−1 at 0.4 and 4 C, respectively, and high capacity retention of 98% after 120 cycles at 0.4 C. As previously discussed in Section 2.1.3 to Section 2.1.5, the volume/mass ratio, morphology, and particle size of the LLZO-based fillers as well as the solid/liquid plasticizers have important effect on the ionic transport and mechanical properties for LLZO-based/polymer SCEs. Thus, the size effect of the LLZO ceramic particles on the intrinsic properties of LLZO-based/PVDF SCEs has been achieved special attention by Cheng's group [130]. It is shown that the LLZO/PVDF-LiClO4 SCE with 10 wt% of mixed-sized fillers of Nb and Al-doped LLZO exhibits high packing density (i.e., lower porosity) and long conducting pathways, leading to high ionic conductivity of 2.6 × 10−4 S cm−1. This value is twice as much as that of the LLZO/PVDF-LiClO4 SCEs with nano- or micrometer-sized LLZO particles as the fillers. Benefitting from the high conductivity and large Li+ transference number, stable and low interfacial resistance, and good mechanical properties, this composite electrolyte is favorable for high performance ASSLBs. Zhao et al. fabricated elastic SCEs (EACN) by filling elastic ionic conductive polymers (PVDF) into well-aligned Li6.4La3Zr2Al0.2O12 (LLZO) nanofiber (NF) films, which were prepared by a low-cost approach of sol-gel electrospinning followed by calcination [131]. The 75 wt% well-orientated and densely packed LLZO NFs in the EACN interacted with PVDF can provide continuous and fast ionic conduction channels, rendering the EACN electrolytes with a high ionic conductivity of 1.16 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 30 °C. Furthermore, the high surface elasticity can maintain an intimate physical contact at the EACN/electrode interfaces, resulting in an ultra-low internal resistance of 87 Ω of the NCA|EACN|Li cell. Meanwhile, the symmetrical Li|EACN|Li battery can display a long-term cycling stability over 700 h and the NCA|EACN|Li battery can show a high initial discharge capacity of 213 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C with a high Coulombic efficiency of > 95% under a wide electrochemical window of 2.7–4.6 V and room temperature. In another work by Hu's group in 2019 [132], a safe and flexible SCE membrane, comprising of 7.5 wt% LLZNO (Li6.75La3Zr1.75Nb0.25O12) particles, PVDF and LiClO4, was fabricated. Benefitting from the strongly coupled effects via interfacial chemical reactions and the synergistic effects between LLZNO and PVDF, the ionic liquid-wetted SCE exhibits a relatively high ionic conductivity of 1.5 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C and can work well in aLiFePO4|LLZNO-PVDF|Li cell both at room and high temperature. In a very recent and important work [133], Thangadurai's group has reported a facile bulk synthesis of SCE based on PVDF and Li6.5La2.5Ba0.5ZrTaO12 for room temperature all-solid-state lithium sulfur battery (ASSLSB), in which the SCE has successfully stabilized by using LiF additives and optimizing the electrolyte composition. The fabricated SCE exhibits an excellent Li+ conductivity of 0.34 mS cm−1 and steady galvanostatic cycling at 0.2 mA cm−2 for more than 800 h at 20 °C. An ASSLSB assembled with the LiF-modified SCE can show a high specific capacity of 936 mAh g−1 and stable cycle performance for 80 cycles at 0.1 C rate under 20 °C. The method of LiF-modified provide a new perspective towards room temperature ASSLBs. To develop SPEs with high ionic conductivity, good interfacial and mechanical properties, as well as superior thermal and electrochemical stabilities simultaneously, PVDF-HFP has been adopted and widely used as the host for SPEs due to its high dielectric constant and high ionic conductivity at room temperature originated from the low crystalline and some functional groups with strong electron withdrawing effect [147]. For example, Zhang and his co-workers firstly reported a LLZO-based hybrid solid electrolyte (HSE) membrane using PVDF–HFP polymer as matrix and 5 wt% LLZO particles as fillers in 2018 [134]. Several advantages, including a large Li+ transference number of 0.61, high mechanical stability, a wide electrochemical window up to 5.3 V as well as high thermal stability, are obtained in this hybrid solid polymer electrolyte (HSPE). However, the ionic conductivity of this HSPE is up to high value of 1.1 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25 °C only when it is infiltrated with 20 µL liquid electrolyte. The LiFePO4|HSPE|Li cell with 20 µL liquid electrolyte shows reduced interfacial resistance and delivers specific discharge capacities of 140 and 100 mAh g−1 at 0.1 and 1 C, respectively, and capacity retention of 92.5% after 180 cycles at 0.5 C and 25 °C. After this work, Li et al. [135] incorporated 10 wt% LLZO NFs into PVDF-HFP matrix to form a PVDF-HFP-LiTFSI-LLZO SCE. Due to the 1-D structure of LLZO NFs provide continuous Li+ transport pathways, an obviously improved ionic conductivity of 9.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 at room temperature is achieved with the presence of small amount of liquid electrolyte. Although PVDF-HFP possesses superior electrochemical stability, thermal stability and mechanical properties compared to PEO, its low ionic conductivity at room temperature still does not meet the needs of practical applications in ASSLBs. Inspired by the approach of chemically introducing cross-linked structure in polymer can effectively improve the ionic conductivity and enhance the dimensional stability [148], Xu et al. [137] chemically attached poly(ethylene glycol) methyl ether methacrylate (POEGMA) to PVDF-HFP by polymerization reaction initiated with ultraviolet light irradiation, and then used this as-prepared novel polymer as the host for the fabrication of the SCE membrane containing LLZTO (Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12) particles. As expected, the as-prepared SCE shows improved chemical/electrochemical performance. However, to obtain excellent battery performance, small amount of liquid electrolyte is still needed to be dropped on the surface of the SCE membrane to enhance the interfacial contact and thus decrease the interfacial resistance between electrolyte membrane and electrodes. Compared to the PEO-based SPEs, the PEC-based solid electrolyte with a single carbonate group [-O-(C = O)-O] has higher Li+ transference capability, which can transfer Li+ more quickly due to the weak interactions between carbonate groups and Li+ [149]. Thus, Chen et al. successfully fabricated high transference number intercalated SCEs by the combination of a solution-casting and hot-pressing method, via inserting PEC-based electrolytes to the interlayer of single ion conductor lithium montmorillonite (LiMNT) [138]. To further enhance the ionic conductivity and mechanical property, tiny fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) additive and poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) binder were introduced into the SCEs. The SCE with optimal composition (i.e. 30PEC-70LiMNT-80LiFSI-15FEC-5PTFE) presents high ionic conductivity of 3.5 × 10−4 S cm−1, a wide electrochemical window of 4.6 V, and high Li+ transference number of 0.83 at 25 °C. Based on the synergistic effect of high transference number of intercalated electrolyte and 3-D Li anode to suppress Li dendrites, the assembled solid-state LiFePO4|SCE|3D Li cell displays good cycling performance, with a high initial specific discharge capacity of 145.9 mAh g−1 and capacity retention of 91.9% after 200 cycles at 0.5 C and 25 °C. In addition, the Al2O3@NCM|SCE|3D Li battery also exhibits good cycling stability, with capacity retention of 92.0% after 100 cycles at 0.2 C and ambient temperature. It is noted that, unlike PEO-based composite electrolytes, the introduction of ceramic filler into the PAN polymer matrix does not significantly change the crystallinity of PAN films containing Li+ salt [150,151]. Therefore, the morphology and filling content of the LLZO-based fillers would play important effects on the ionic conductivity of the PAN-based SCEs. Yang et al. systematically studied the effects of filler type (active/inactive), LLZO with different compositions (undoped/doped) and morphologies (nanowire/nanoparticle) on the properties of the as-prepared PAN-based SCEs [139]. By solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies, they suggested that LLZO NWs partially modify the PAN polymer matrix and create preferential pathways for Li+ conduction through the modified polymer regions. Thus, SCEs with LLZO NWs as ceramic fillers show greatly improved ionic conductivity of around 10−4 S cm−1 at 20 °C, specifically, a SCE with 5 wt% LLZO NWs exhibits ionic conductivity of 1.31 × 10−4 S cm−1. Furthermore, the Al- or Ta-doped LLZO NWs as fillers do not have a significant influence on the ionic conductivity of the SCEs. Similarly, the LLZO nanowires has been dispersed into PMMA matrix to construct a PMMA-based SCE, and improved ionic conductivity of 2.20 × 10−5 S cm−1 has also been achieved, despite it is much lower than that of the above-mentioned PAN-based SCEs with LLZO NWs. This difference ionic conductivity between the PMMA-based and PAN-based SCE indicates that the change of polymer matrix may lead to big properties difference for the SCEs. It has also been demonstrated that a cross-linked polymer substrate can offer good interfacial contact with the electrode and compensate for volume variation during the long cycling, especially when using Li metal, silicon, and sulfur as the electode materials [152]. Furthermore, the cross-linked structure can decrease the tacticity of the polymer hosts, resulting in low crystallinity, higher mechanical strength and structural stability over the melting point [63,105,153]. Therefore, the cross-linked polymer substrates with segmental flexibility and bulk structural stability should be suitable for SCEs to improve ionic conductivity and mechanical strength. To obtain efficient Li+ movement at the micro-scale and enough mechanical strength at the macro-scale simultaneously, Tian et al. prepared a cross-linked polyethyleneglycol by the polymerization of terminal active groups and then used it as the polymer matrix to construct the SCE with LLZO fillers (LLZ-BEPEO) [141]. This SCE delivers ionic conductivity above 5.0 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 45 °C, a stable electrochemical window above 4.51 V, and smaller interfacial resistance and superior wettability than the LLZO-PEO electrolyte. Furthermore, this LLZO filler-embedded cross-linked host can maintain mechanically intact above the melting point, enabling the ASSLBs to work well even at high temperatures. Thus, the solid-state NCM111|LLZ-BEPEO|Li battery possesses high capacity retention of 82.8% after 70 cycles at C/25 under 45 °C. A new type of garnet-rich SCEs for dendrite-free, high-rate ASSLBs has been developed very recently [142]. The 3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl methacrylate serves as the coupling agent that enables the silane-modified Li6.28La3Al0.24Zr2O12 (s@LLAZO) NFs with high content (up to 70 wt%) and fully embedded in the PEGDA matrix, which can significantly reduce the agglomeration effect. Therefore, the s@LLZAO/PEGDA SCE with 50 wt% LLAZO displays high ionic conductivity of 4.7 × 10−4 S cm−1, large Li+ transference number of 0.61, a wide electrochemical stability window (up to 5.0 V) and excellent cycle stability. The LiFePO4|s@LLZAO/PEGDA|Li and NMC333|s@LLZAO/PEGDA|Li cells both exhibit excellent cycling stability and extraordinarily high rate capability at room temperature. This novel design of SCEs using the s@LLAZO NFs as fillers provides a promising preparation route for new SCEs with superior performances. The dilemma is the highly flexible polymers show improved ionic transport properties but fail in terms of rigidity. Therefore, investigation on SPEs with high comprehensive properties is always on the road. Polymer blending technology is a promising method to regulate the crystallinity of single polymer [154,155]. Recently, incorporating LLZO-based ceramics into the mixed polymer matrixes to construct SCEs with superior large Li+ transference number, high ionic conductivity, suppression of lithium dendrite growth and the improvement of battery performances has received some attention [143–145]. For example, He et al., prepared a flexible LLZO-based SCE by using the homogenously dispersed nano-sized LLZO, PEC, P(VdF-HFP) and LiFSI as raw materials and solution-casting method [143]. Optimum Li+ transference number of 0.82, ionic conductivity of 5.24 × 10−5 S cm−1, stable interfacial resistance of 124 Ω cm−2 at 55 °C and a good electrochemical stability window of 5.0 V are obtained for the 70LLZO-30PEC-5P(VdF-HFP)−60LiFSI (i.e. 7.0 g LLZO, 3.0 g PEC, 0.5 g P(VdF-HFP) and 6.0 g LiFSI) composite electrolyte. The assembled LiFePO4|0LLZO-30PEC-5P(VdF-HFP)−60LiFSI|Li battery displays a discharge specific capacity of 121.4 mAh g−1 (at 1 C) and excellent capacity retention of 96.5% after 100 cycles at 1 C under 55 °C. Li et al. optimized the composition of (PEO/PVDF) matrix and introduced Li6.2Ga0.1La3Zr1.5Bi0.5O12 (LLZO) ceramic powders into the host to fabricate SCEs [144]. It is found that the PEO/PVDF blend matrix with a weight ratio of 7:3 displays a low melting point and crystallinity as well as high thermo stability. The SCE containing this PEO/PVDF (7:3) blend host and 10 wt% of LLZO exhibits the highest conductivity of 4.2 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 30 °C. Very recently, Cha et al. have synthesized a self-standing, flexible, highly ionic conductive, and electrochemically stable SCEs composed of a mixed PEO/(ethylene glycol) dimethyl ether (PEGDME) matrix, LLZO ceramic filler and LiTFSI [145]. Herein, PEGDME as a plasticizer determined by the authors with 10 wt% leads to a significant increase in the ionic conductivity, which is approximately six times higher than that of the SCE without the plasticizer. Thus, a NCM622|SCE|Li full cell can show an initial reversible capacity of 157 mAh g−1 and a coulombic efficiency of 97.7% at 0.1 C under 60 °C, and a capacity retention of ~86% after 100 cycles at 0.5 C. In addition, although the full cell with a high NCM622 mass loading of 7.7 mg cm−2, it can deliver an initial discharge capacity of ~160 mA h g−1 and maintain a high capacity retention of ~87.5% even after 60 cycles at 0.1 C and 60 °C, suggesting possible application of this SCE in a practical ASSLB. Novel polymers (PPC, PEC, PVDF, PVDF-HFP and PAN etc.) combined with LLZO-based ceramics are capable of achieving high ionic conductivity, large lithium ion transference number, good mechanical strength, high thermal stability, and stable electrochemical performances against Li metal. Furthermore, many all-solid-state batteries equipped with these SCEs can exhibit favorable electrochemical performances at ambient temperature [127,129,131,133,135,137,138,142], high temperature [140,141,143–145], and even at a wide temperature range [126,132,136]. However, these polymers-based SCEs also remain some challenges for practical application in ASSLBs. Firstly, the interaction between LLZTO-based fillers and polymer-lithium salt as well as the mechanism of the improved intrinsic properties and electrochemical performance of LLZO-based/PPC SCEs are still unclear. Secondly, the PVDF-HFP-based composite electrolytes still need small amount of liquid electrolyte to decrease the interfacial impedance between electrodes and solid electrolytes [131–135]. Finally, most of the LLZO-based/novel polymer SCEs are more expensive compared to the LLZO-based/PEO SCEs. Therefore, other novel types of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs beyond these polymers with superior intrinsic properties for good electrochemical performance and high safe ASSLBs, and their low-cost and nontoxic fabrication procedures are need to be further developed. 4 Understanding the Li+ pathways within LLZO-based/polymer SCEs The hybrid of LLZO-based electrolytes and polymer electrolytes can generate multiple types of SCEs, including LLZO-based/polymer SCEs with uniform dispersion of LLZO-based fillers and LLZO-based/polymer layered SCEs. In the case of layered SCEs, polymers usually act as buffer layers to decrease the electrolyte/electrode interfacial resistance and suppress lithium dendrite growth [112].
