When these layered SCEs are used in practical batteries, the lithium ions have to pass through the existing interfaces between the polymer and LLZO-based ceramics for further transmission [156]. However, these interfaces are highly resistive originated from high activation energies [157], which greatly affects the intrinsic properties of these layered SCEs. Differently, LLZO-based/polymer SCEs with uniform dispersion of LLZO-based fillers generally exhibit improved ionic conductivity, electrochemical and thermal stability, as well as mechanical strength owing to the interactions between LLZO-based conductive ceramics and polymer hosts [25,129,158]. Therefore, understanding the interactions between LLZO-based ceramics and polymers is of great significance for further improving the comprehensive performances of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs. One of the most important intrinsic properties for solid-state electrolytes is to have as high as possible ionic conductivity at room temperature. Previous investigation results suggest that the dispersion of LLZO-based ceramics into polymer matrixes can achieve enhanced ionic conductivity due to the following three traditional reasons. 1) The increased active Li+ concentration. LLZO-based fillers as active ceramic filler can provide some active Li+ and second ion-transport channel [54]. 2) The improved Li+ mobility. Firstly, the LLZO-based fillers can decrease the crystallinity and stabilize the amorphous phase of polymers, and thereby contributes to improvements in the Li+ mobility [159,160], and secondly, the LLZO-based fillers with Lewis acid-base character that can adsorb anions and then break up the ion pair, leading to increased dissociation of lithium salts [54]. 3) The percolating interfacial effect. A thin surface space charge region with the promotion of Li+ conduction is formed at the interface between the LLZO-based fillers and polymer matrixes [81,158,161]. As demonstrated by a large number of previous review papers [16,25,158], the synergistic role of the active Li+ concentration, Li+ mobility and Li+ transport pathways affected by the different compositions, morphologies and filling amount of the LLZO-based fillers, finally determine the ionic conductivity and Li+ transference number of the SCEs. Therefore, rational construction of a LLZO-based/polymer SCE with the maximum ionic conductivity should take many factors into consideration. Considering the important influence of Li+ transport pathways or conduction mechanisms on the ionic conductivity, it is necessary to understand the Li+ conduction mechanism of the SCEs. Although some characterization techniques, such as Infrared (IR) and Raman spectroscopies, have been applied to investigate the Li+ conduction mechanism on basis of the change of salt anions [162], selective isotope labeling combined with high-resolution solid-state Li nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) to achieve direct information about Li+ transfer mechanism within the SCEs are more convincing [84,163,164]. As early as 2016, Hu's group first identified the Li+ sites and probed the Li+ pathway within a (PEO18-LiClO4)-based SCE containing 50 wt% LLZO fillers [163]. Specifically, Fig. 8 (a) shows the three possible Li environments within this SCE (LLZO/PEO-LiCLO4), including the Li in PEO-LiClO4 polymer matrix, the LLZO grain, and the PEO/LLZO interface, and Fig. 8(b) depicts the corresponding high-resolution 6Li NMR spectrum of PEO-LiClO4 SPE, pure phase LLZO, and LLZO/PEO-LiCLO4 SCE. Comparison of the 6Li NMR shown in Fig. 8(b), the shoulder at ~ 1.4 ppm was assigned to the Li at the PEO/LLZO interface. A possible Li+ transfer pathways can be determined by a symmetric cell of 6Li|LLZO/PEO-LiCLO4|6Li cell (Fig. 8(c)). During the electrochemical cycle, 6Li+ were stripped from one 6Li electrode into the hybrid electrolyte driven by electric potential and then diffused through the electrolyte to deposit onto the other 6Li electrode, and meanwhile, 7Li+ were partially replaced by 6Li+ within the electrolyte every time when 6Li+ move through the electrolyte, leaving a trail for the Li ion pathway. Therefore, the Li+ pathways within the composite electrolyte can be revealed by comparing the amount of 6Li and 7Li NMR of pristine and cycled composite electrolytes. The final results indicate that the 6Li spectrum of the cycled composite electrolyte exhibits obviously increased intensity (up to 39%) for the LLZO peak, and only a 6% enhancement for the interfacial Li and LiClO4 resonances compared with the pristine LLZO/PEO-LiCLO4 electrolyte (Fig. 8(d)), which indicate that Li+ mainly pass through the LLZO ceramic particles rather than the interface or the PEO. However, in the composite electrolyte of LLZO/PEO-LiCLO4 with an additive of tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME), Li+ is mainly transported via TEGDME-associated phases, not the ceramic LLZO or PEO or PEO/LLZO interface [164]. Soon after, they further studied the relationships between the composition and ionic conductivity within the SCEs in detail [84], which is determined by the synergistic effect of ion transport pathways, ion mobility, and active ion concentration. The results indicate that with the increase in the ratio of LLZO, the ionic transport pathways transit from polymer to ceramic routes due to the formation of a connected percolation network (Fig. 8(e)). Meanwhile, within the LLZO/PEO SCE, the active ionic concentration was increased, and the ionic mobility was decreased due to the blocked Li+ pathways caused by the LLZO fillers. These simultaneous variations in the three parameters can explain the observed variation trend of ionic conductivity in SCEs with different compositions. Similar to their previous work [164], the liquid additives change the Li+ transport pathways and increase ionic mobility, thus improving Li+ conductivity obviously. Furthermore, a higher content of LLZO fillers results in more stable electrochemical performances of the LLZO/PEO SCEs. Except the above- mentioned viewpoints on the Li+ tranfer pathways within the LLZO-based/PEO SCEs revealed by Hu's group, some additional standpoints have also been proposed. For example, Guo's group suggested that the improvement in ionic conductivity in the Ga-doped LLZO NPs/PEO (16% vol. of Ga-doped LLZO)SCE was mainly ascribed to the ionic conduction in the thin space charge regions and the percolation of the space charge regions, which was generated at the interface between the PEO matrix and the Ga-LLZO nanoparticles (Fig. 8(f)) and observed clearly by TEM (Fig. 8(g)) [81]. In a very recent work on the investigation of the Li+ transportation mechanism in the LLZO/PEO-LiTFSI (LLZO = Li6.55Ga0.15La3Zr2O12) SCE with 10 wt% LLZO reported by Zagórski et.al [165], they indicated that the total Li+ ion conductivity was governed by the polymer matrix rather than the LLZO ceramics. It was found that the high interfacial resistance (~104 Ω cm2) between the LLZO particles and the PEO-LiTFSI matrix leads to a slightly decreased Li+ ionic conductivity from 7.0 × 10−4 S cm−1 for the PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte to 4.5 × 10−4 S cm−1 for the LLZO/PEO-LiTFSI SCE. Furthermore, the polymer is physically constrained between the ceramic particles at high content of LLZO fillers (above 40 vol%), resulting in restricted chain mobility and thus limited ionic conduction. In addition, they suggested that the dynamic transfer phenomenon of Li+ between the LLZO surfaces and the surrounding polymer chains, determined by using 7Li NMR 2D exchange spectroscopy (ESXY), played a key role in kinetically stabilizing the interface with Li metal electrode. Except the LLZO-based/PEO SCEs, the Li+ pathways in another composite electrolyte consisting of 5 wt% LLZO NWs, PAN and LiCLO4 has also been studied [139], in which the solid-state NMR results indicate that LLZO NWs partially modify the PAN polymer matrix and then create preferential pathways for Li+ conduction through the modified polymer regions, due to the LLZO content is too small to form a connected percolation network. Although the preferred Li+ pathway within the LLZO-based/polymer SCEs have been investigated by solid-state NMR technique and some inspiring results have been achieved, in-situ and/or other advanced test methods to more intuitively and accurately reveal the Li+ pathways within SCEs are also urgently needed, which could contribute to the designing of novel SCEs with improved ionic conductivity. 5 LLZO-based/polymer SCEs for ASSLBs beyond the ionic conductivity The high ionic conductivity of a SCE is the prerequisite for an ASSLB with high electrochemical performance. However, the interfacial and chemical/electrochemical stability of the SCEs directly determine whether they can compatible with electrodes, especially for high-voltage cathodes. It has been demonstrated that the incorporating LLZO-based ceramics into polymer matrixes can obtain improved electrochemical stability in comparison to the parental polymer electrolytes because of many explanations [16,52,102,158]: 1) the super-high oxidative stability of LLZO up to ~ 9 V vs. Li+/Li, 2) the higher decomposition potentials of lithium salt anion due to their immobilization on the LLZO surface through Lewis acid-base interactions, 3) the dipole-dipole interactions of LLZO and the polymer that alter the latter electron transition energy level and elevate its oxidative decomposition potential, and 4) interactions of the LLZO with both the polymer (e.g., PEO) and lithium salt anion (usually, TFSI− or ClO4 −). In previous investigations, the electrochemical stability is generally evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), where an inert stainless steel or nickel was used as the working blocking electrodes in a symmetric Li metal cell. In these cases, however, the values of stable electrochemical windows are often be overestimated. A practical working electrode usually composed of high-surface area carbon as the conductive additive that decreases the electrochemical stability of the SCE. Furthermore, the high-voltage transition metal oxide cathodes also catalyze the oxidative decomposition of the polymers, leading to unstable electrochemical performance. For instance, a PEO-based hybrid electrolyte delivers a high stable voltage window from the LSV result where an inert electrode was used, while it shows poor cycle stability when combined with a layered oxide [166]. To address these issues, by adopting of vapor grown carbon fiber (VGCF) instead of Super-P as the conductive agent may provide an alternative route for the preparation of high-voltage cathode with high electrochemical stability [48]. It has also been suggested that solid electrolytes are thermodynamically unstable in contact with lithium metal [52,167]. And meanwhile, the growth of lithium dendrites is usually observed during the long-term cycling, especially at high current density. Although garnet-type LLZO displays the lowest reduction potential (0.05 V vs. Li/Li+) and the least favorable decomposition reaction energy among the solid electrolytes, enabling LLZO to be a electrochemically compatible with Li anode [167], some polymers (such as PAN, PEO and PPC) and the salt anion in the LLZO-based/polymer SCEs are easily reduced [52,168,169]. Therefore, reducing the polymers' degradation are ensure to guarantee the stability and safety of an ASSLB, despite some interfacial reactions between lithium metal and polymers can improve the interfacial compatibility and reduce the interfacial impedance [169]. Thus, establishing a stable interface with the lithium electrode to suppress the lithium dendrite formation and growth as well as reducing the high interfacial resistances between electrolytes and Li anode are necessary and significantly important, which may be realized based on the positive role originated from the LLZO and other lithium ion conductors as the fillers in the SCEs [170]. Also, constructing of a double-layer (composite) polymer electrolyte or an asymmetric composite polymer electrolyte to simultaneously satisfy the demands of Li-metal anode and cathode is encouraged [171]. Based on the most of the as-prepared composite polymer electrolytes reported by previous investigation works, the thickness of them must also to be reduced because of its important role in the Li+ transmission and ASSLBs` energy densities. In addition to high ionic conductivity and interfacial stability, mechanical property and thermal stability are also very important for the practical application of the SCEs, which ensure the batteries to work safely at elevated temperatures. The minimum requirements on mechanical property and thermal stability are above 30 MPa and 150 °C, respectively [54]. Generally, the requirements of mechanical strength for the cathode and anode electrodes are contradictory. In the cathode, the SCE is expected to as soft as possible to decrease the interfacial resistance, while it should be hard enough to suppress the lithium dendrite growth when using lithium metal as the anode. Incorporating LLZO into polymer matrix with optimum content can obtain suitable mechanical strength and thus meet the above requirements at the same time. Alternatively, polymer as the buffer layer between electrodes and LLZO pellet can also effectively decrease the interfacial resistance and suppress the growth of lithium dendrite. Concerning thermal stability of the SCE, it can be revealed through thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) and flammability test. Generally, the decomposition temperature of LLZO-based/polymers SCEs will be reduced because of the decreased crystallinity of polymers after the addition of LLZO-based fillers. However, LLZO-based/polymers SCEs generally exhibit better flame retardancy performance compared with their corresponding polymer electrolytes due to the exceptional heat-resistance property of LLZO-based fillers. 6 Summary and perspectives In summary, LLZO-based/polymer SCEs generally exhibit higher ionic conductivity, superior thermal and electrochemical stability than pure polymer-based electrolytes, and better flexibility as well as lower interfacial resistance than LLZO-based ceramics electrolytes. Uniformly incorporating LLZO-based ceramics into polymer matrix can form from "ceramic-in-polymer" to "polymer-in-ceramic" SCEs with the increasing of the amount of LLZO-based fillers. Within these SCEs, the compositions, phase structures, particle sizes, filling amount, morphologies, and degree of dispersion of the LLZO-based fillers have large impacts on the intrinsic properties of the as-prepared SCEs and their corresponding performances in ASSLBs. The LLZO-based ceramics in cubic phase have been extensively studied as the fillers due to their intrinsic higher ionic conductivity than LLZO in tetragonal phase. In terms of enhancing ionic conductivity, LLZO-based fillers in nanometer-size exhibit a greater advantage than micro-sized fillers because smaller particles possess a larger specific surface area, which is more conducive to the occurrence of percolation. However, nano-sized LLZO-based fillers are prone to agglomeration, making them difficult to uniformly disperse in polymer matrix. Compared with nanoparticles, LLZO-based ceramics with structures in nanofibers, nanowires, nanosheets and 3-D framework as the fillers can provide more effective ways for improving the comprehensive performances of the SCEs because they can offer interconnected and continuous Li+ transfer pathways. However, the preparation of LLZO-based ceramic with unique morphology via a low-cost and large-scale route is urgently required. Influenced by many complex factors, there is an optimal filling amount of LLZO-based ceramics in SCEs. With the increase of the amount of LLZO-based fillers, the ionic conductivity of the SCEs increases firstly and then decreases due to the polymer matrix is physically constrained between the ceramic particles at high content of LLZO-based fillers, while the mechanical strength as well as chemical/thermal/electrochemical stability generally increase linearly. In addition to uniform dispersion of LLZO-based ceramics into PEO matrix, LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs have been developed for addressing the various interfacial requirements of the Li anode and cathode, maintaining the intimate contact between the electrolytes and electrodes during the long cycle. Novel polymers (such as PEC, PVDF, PPC, PAN, PVDF-HFP, etc.) with unique properties instead of PEO as the polymer matrixes for novel SCEs have also attracted special attention. Compared to PEO-based SCEs, LLZO-based/novel polymers SCEs exhibit higher ionic conductivity and lager lithium transference number at room temperature, better thermal and electrochemical stability as well as enhanced mechanical strength. However, these novel polymers' cost, film-forming ability and large-scale preparation route should be taken into consideration in the view of practical applications. Although the LLZO-based/polymer SCEs and their corresponding ASSLBs have been attracted special attention and encouraging results have been received, there are still many issues need to be solved to meet their large application in practical ASSLBs. Some perspectives are proposed based on the above summary and discussions: (1) Although most of reported LLZO-based/polymer SCEs can show ionic conductivity of ~ 10−4 S cm−1 at high and/or room temperature, which is still much smaller than that of liquid electrolytes (~ 10−2 S cm−1) and cannot well meet the practical need for commercial ASSLBs. Thus, the ionic conductivity of these SCEs at room temperature requires to be further improved. (2) The Li+ transport pathways/mechanisms of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs have been traced by solid-state NMR technology combined with 6Li→7Li isotope replacement method, however, the results are still not exhaustive. Thus, revealing the Li+ transport pathways through in-situ and/or other advanced techniques are encouraged, which contribute to the structure design of novel LLZO-based/polymer SCEs with enhanced ionic conductivity. (3) Compared to zero-dimensional particles, LLZO-based fillers with unique structure offer superior advantages for improving the comprehensive performances of the SCEs, especially in terms of ionic conductivity and mechanical strength. Thus, a low-cost and large-scale route for preparing LLZO-based fillers with unique structure is urgently needed. (4) The interfacial characters, including interfaces between Li and SCEs, cathode and SCEs, and LLZO-based fillers and polymers, play key roles in the power density and cycling performance of ASSLBs and should be paid more attention. In general, a SCE is required to be soft enough to reduce the interfacial impedance at the positive electrode, while which is required to possess as high as possible mechanical strength to suppress the growth of lithium dendrites at the negative electrode. In this regard, it is difficult for a single SCE to simultaneously satisfy both requirements for Li anode and cathode. Therefore, designing the asymmetric LLZO-based/polymer SCEs is a promising solution. (5) Many reports have claimed that their synthesized LLZO-based/polymer SCEs display stable voltage window up to 5 V or more, but most of the assembled ASSLBs in their works are LiFePO4-based cells. To obtain as high as possible energy density for ASSLBs, high-voltage cathode materials, such as NCM, NCA, LiFe1- x Mn x PO4, should be recommended. In this regard, the high-voltage cathode materials modified by functional coatings and other efficient conductive additives for the preparation of stable electrodes are worthy of more attention. Liansheng Li received the B.E. degree from Shenyang Ligong University in 2016 and the M.E. degree from South China University of Technology in 2019. Currently, he is pursuing his Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Prof. Yuan-Fu Deng at South China University of Technology. His research interest is on matching of high-voltage cathode materials with solid electrolytes for all-solid-state lithium battery. Yuan-Fu Deng is currently a professor in School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at South China University of Technology (SCUT). He previously held positions of an Associate Professor (2009–2015) and a lecture (2005–2009) at SCUT. He received his Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2005, and worked as a post doctor in the Department of Chemistry at University of Waterloo, Canada in 2007–2008. His research interests focus on the development of novel materials, structures and characterization methods for application in electrochemical energy storage and catalysis. Guohua Chen is currently a chair professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University (PolyU). Prof. Chen received his Bachelor degree in Chemical Engineering from Dalian University of Technology in 1984, and Master and Ph.D. degrees in Chemical Engineering from McGill University in 1989 and 1994, respectively. Prof. Chen joined HKUST in 1994 and was promoted as professor in 2008 and acted as an Endowed Otto Poon Charitable Foundation Professor at PolyU in 2019. Prof. Chen's research areas include: electrochemical technologies and materials for energy and environment, advanced oxidation technologies for water and wastewater treatment, solid waste management, and drying of solids.

coredata.dc:description: Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), such as polyethylene oxide (PEO), are characteristic of good flexibility and excellent processability, but they suffer from low ionic conductivity and small Li+ transference number at ambient temperature. Inorganic solid electrolytes (ISEs), garnet-type Li7La3Zr2O12 and its derivatives (LLZO-based) in particular, possess high ionic conductivity at room temperature, wide electrochemical stability window, large Li+ transference number as well as good stability against Li metal anode. Nevertheless, lithium dendrites growth, interfacial contact issue and brittle nature of LLZO-based ceramic electrolytes prevent their practical applications. In response to these shortcomings, LLZO-based/polymer solid composite electrolytes (SCEs), taking complementary advantages of two kinds of electrolytes, and thus simultaneously improving the electrode wettability, ionic conductivity and mechanical strength, have been made to develop high-performance SCEs in recent years. Herein, the intrinsic properties and research progress of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs, including LLZO-based/PEO SCEs (LLZO-based/PEO SCEs with uniform dispersion of LLZO-based fillers and LLZO-based/PEO layered SCEs) and LLZO-based/novel polymers SCEs, are summarized. Besides, comprehensive updates on their applications in solid-state batteries are also presented. Finally, challenges and perspectives of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs for advanced all-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs) are suggested. This review paper aims to provide systematic research progress of LLZO-based/polymer SCEs, to allow for more efficient and target-oriented research on improving LLZO-based/polymer SCEs.
